Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: GP-EXTRA: Geoscience Engagement and Outreach (GEO) - High-Impact Integrated Academic and Professional Experiences
Award.AbstractNarration:
Few students enter undergraduate programs understanding what the geosciences are or that they are part of a science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) curriculum. Yet, high paying, high demand jobs in the geosciences and the need for diversity in these fields means these students may miss an opportunity to put their interests in science to work. This is especially true of students beginning their undergraduate education at two year institutions, which are play an ever increasing role in the landscape of higher education. Nearly 54% of minority students in STEM begin their undergraduate education at a community college, making efforts to engage and support such students and better prepare them to transfer to and succeed at 4-year institutions is so important. The Geoscience Engagement and Outreach (GEO) project promotes progress in science for students through the recruitment, mentoring and support of a cohort of two-year college students from underrepresented populations. Activities include faculty mentored research in a sub-set of geoscience subdisciplines, as well as skill building for careers to produce graduates prepared for the expectations of future employers. Documenting the potential of cross-institutional, integrated research and education experiences being developed through this project for retaining diverse students in the geosciences contributes to the literature on STEM recruitment and retention. The project also is expected to increase the number and caliber of faculty available to mentor undergraduates and foster continued education in the geosciences.

The GEO project is addressing barriers to engagement, recruitment, and retention of diverse students in the geosciences pipeline through an innovative three-institution collaboration that combines and leverages the strengths of Santa Fe College, a two year teaching institution; the University of Florida, a four year research institution; and the Orlando Science Center, a nonprofit informal education and outreach venue. The GEO project offers students authentic geoscience research experiences explicitly integrated with practical applications and scaffolded to classroom work. Project goals include: (1) fostering retention of the participating GEO students at Santa Fe College and transfer into Bachelor's degree programs in the geosciences, (2) strengthening collaborations among Santa Fe College teaching faculty, University of Florida researchers, and Orlando Science Center informal science educators, and (3) increasing student interest in geoscience careers through public outreach development of resources for in-service teachers. GEO's three phases of seminar-style teaching, research mentoring with outreach project development and delivery, and a culminating capstone experience scaffold the program elements into an emerging geoscience Associates degree at Santa Fe College. The project is designed to support three annual cohorts of 6 students each, with integration of peer- and supervisor-mentoring and collaborations among the three institutions. The project is targeted toward recruitment of underrepresented populations and their retention in geoscience fields. University of Florida faculty are mentoring student research in the geoscience sub-disciplines of meteorology, soil hydrology, and geoscience and STEM education. The Orlando Science Center is supervising a paid 6-week summer internship that emphasizes communications and outreach skills development. GEO students are designing and conducting outreach with diverse public audiences, teachers and high school volunteers through OSC's Otronicon. Continuation of research and outreach activities during the Fall semester culminates in the completion of a two year degree by GEO cohort students and their transfer to a four year geosciences program, prepared to continue and thrive alongside their four year institution peers. Project evaluation is measuring student content gain, using the Geoscience Concept Inventory; in addition, increases in a student's science identity and potential interest in pursuing geoscience careers are being assessed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Geoscience Education and Outreach (GEO) program provided 20 undergraduates from Santa Fe College multi-semester research experiences in geoscience at the University of Florida (UF). Each year for three years, cohorts of six to seven students worked in groups with one of three UF mentors: one from meteorology who conducts tropical cyclone research, one from education who conducts learning research with public audiences, and one from agricultural engineering, who conducts soil moisture research. The students conducted original research starting in January, continuing through the summer, and culminating in a poster presentation at the Santa Fe College Research in Undergraduate Education Festival. Students worked with a variety of mentors, from undergraduate peers from UF, to graduate students and postdoctoral researchers as well as research staff. Three students presented their research at a regional research conference, the SouthEastern Division of the American Association of Geographers in 2018, two as undergraduate posters and one as a live presentation. One of the undergraduate poster presenters won the best undergraduate poster award; this student presented that work additionally at a Florida Society of Geographers meeting as well as the national meeting of the American Association of Geographers. The student who presented live at SEDAAG presented the research work again during a study abroad trip to Peru.

This research experience was part of a collaborative effort with NSF project ICER 1540729, which incorporated the research in a year-long extracurricular experience for students underrepresented in geosciences. Throughout the program, researchers at UF also evaluated the students? progress through interviews and surveys. We found that students faced typical barriers to participation in research including communication issues particularly with the research mentors and across the two institutions in the program, mismatches of experiences with expectations, and time and money constraints. We found that even though we had paid the students for part of the program, the stipends were insufficient to free students completely from part-time employment which interfered with their success in the program. Program revisions over the years alleviated but did not eliminate communication issues.

To date, we found that the program did not change students? knowledge of geoscience as measured by simple scoring of number of correct answers on a subset of questions from a standard geoscience concepts test. However, preliminary analysis does suggest that participants did increase their science identities. That is, program participants identified themselves as scientists more strongly after the program than before participating.

We found that students benefited in multiple ways from participation in the program. In particular, students found the research and internships most valuable for providing real-world job experience. The students valued these experiences even when the experiences helped clarify jobs they did not wish to pursue. Students also found the opportunities to build their networks with the college and university faculty and staff valuable. Anecdotally, even students who did not complete the research or the whole program found aspects of it valuable and were able to use their experiences in securing future internships or transfer to other four-year college programs.

The UF project has produced eight conference presentations for education, meteorology, geography, and geophysical sciences audiences. We also have three journal manuscripts on the research experiences, overall program evaluation, and programmatic design and recommendations under review or near to submission for review as of November 2019. Through the program, the undergraduate participants also contributed to publishable-quality research with the mentors, and these publications with the participants as co-authors are in preparation.

The faculty mentors from UF also benefitted from participating in the project in learning to work with a broader population of students than we had before. Previously, we all had recruited students differently, either through our department, our courses, or UF?s Center for Undergraduate Research. The GEO students challenged us to be more flexible with our working styles and understanding of what success could look like for the student experience. One of our most successful research students, who presented at the national research meeting, almost did not start the program because they were not sure they could participate in all of the parts. And even that student had to step away from the research at times to deal with other life issues rather than pursuing the project non-stop. Finally, one of the UF mentors was recruited to participate in a panel on undergraduate research at the upcoming SEDAAG conference based on her work in this NSF project.
